newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatian power firm needs $151 bln for repairs.
newsitem.headline: Croatian power firm needs $151 bln for repairs.

text.p: Croatia's state-owned electrical company HEP said on Thursday that it would need $151 million to repair war-damaged infrastructure in the last Serb-held enclave in the country, state news agency Hina said.
The enclave of Eastern Slavonia, which has been held by separatist Serbs since 1991 and is now under interim U.N. control, is due to revert to Croatian rule by 1997.
The area is now linked to the electricity network of neigbouring Serbia and will have to be reconnected to the Croatian system pending its integration.

"(In talks with local Serbs) it was agreed that HEP, as the owner of the facilities, would organise the repairement," HEP's Eastern Slavonia committee head Vencel Lasic was quoted by Hina as saying. Lasic said a key transformator in Ernestinovo and power lines, which suffered almost total destruction, would swallow 30-36 million German marks.
HEP earlier said it would channel channel its 53.5 million kuna net profit for 1995 into repairs of damaged infrastructure.
